item.title: How Rob Reiner Created His Comedy Legacy
item.description: These moments from his movies brought the laughs, in many different ways.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: The 25 Most Notable Movies of 2025: ‘KPop Demon Hunters,’ ‘Roofman’ and More
item.description: We polled film experts in the newsroom. These are the titles that stuck with us this year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)
If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)

item.title: Will the Oscars Make Room for ‘Difficult’ Women for 2026’s Best Actress Category?
item.description: Rose Byrne, Jennifer Lawrence and Amanda Seyfried give great performances as women who buck convention. But some voters prize ‘likability’ above all else.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)

item.title: The Most Magical, Moving Four Minutes in Music
item.description: Ravel’s depiction of an enchanted garden is so simple and wistful, I never want it to end.
item.dc:creator: David Allen

item.title: Dutch Return ‘Java Man’ Bones, With 40,000 Fossils Set to Follow
item.description: The items were taken in the late 19th century from what was then called the Dutch East Indies. Indonesia had been trying to get them back for decades.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: A skull cap, right, part of a set of prehistoric bones known as “Java Man,” was returned by the Netherlands to Indonesia on Wednesday.

item.title: How Track Star Became a YouTube and TikTok Music Phenomenon
item.description: “Track Star” is the YouTube series that brings out the music lover in celebrities and civilians alike.
item.dc:creator: Jessica M. Goldstein
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Coyne, the host of the popular online show “Track Star,” quizzes people on identifying songs.

item.title: ‘Paddington: The Musical’: At Just 4 Feet, He’s London’s Biggest New Stage Star
item.description: Audiences are falling in love with the title character in “Paddington: The Musical.” Bringing such a beloved bear to the stage was “a huge responsibility,” the show’s director said.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Kalpesh Lathigra
item.media:credit: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times

item.title: Oscars Reach Deal With YouTube
item.description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said it had reached a deal with YouTube for exclusive rights to the show starting in 2029.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Conan O’Brien hosting the 97th Academy Awards in March.

item.title: How ‘Fallout’ Gave Sex Appeal to an Irradiated Ghoul With No Nose
item.description: Just ahead of the Season 2 premiere, the co-creator Geneva Robertson-Dworet talked about the challenge of finding fun in a nuclear apocalypse.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:credit: Maggie Shannon for The New York Times
item.media:description: “To me, the thing that makes the Fallout games unique is the tone,” Geneva Robertson-Dworet said, noting their balance of “moral dilemmas” and the “sense of wit and irony.”

item.title: A Pipe Organist Invites You to Bliss Out to Her Dreamy Colors
item.description: Ellen Arkbro makes music that shifts and churns with scant regard for harmonic convention. She’s one of the most interesting composers for her instrument working today.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Dickson and Gordon Welters

item.title: Broadway Shows Closing Soon: ‘The Queen of Versailles,’ ‘Waiting for Godot’ and More
item.description: Catch Kristin Chenoweth basking in the excess, and Bill and Ted having a Beckettian adventure, before the curtain comes down on their productions and others.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: Alex Winter as Vladimir, Keanu Reeves as Estragon and Brandon J. Dirden, lying on ground, as Pozzo in “Waiting for Godot” at the Hudson Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘The Voice of Hind Rajab’ Review: When Help Won’t Arrive
item.description: Kaouther Ben Hania’s dramatized feature about a Palestinian girl who is killed in Gaza City is both powerfully direct and purposefully removed.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘The BFG’ Enchants With Puppets and Pantomime Spirit
item.description: There is plenty of stimulation for young theatergoers in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s adaptation of Roald Dahl’s beloved book.
item.dc:creator: Houman Barekat

item.title: Late Night Shades Trump’s Impromptu ‘Liar-side Chat’
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel called the president’s last-minute speech “a surprise prime-time episode of ‘The Worst Wing’ tonight on every channel.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Dinaw Mengestu Will Be New President of PEN America
item.description: The novelist Dinaw Mengestu will lead the literary group at a time of escalating threats to free expression at home and abroad.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dinaw Mengestu, who was born in Ethiopia and moved to the United States when he was 2, has published four novels.

item.title: Hans van Manen, Celebrated Dutch Choreographer, Is Dead at 93
item.description: He rose from poverty to become one of the Netherlands’ most revered dance makers, creating more than 150 avant-garde works in a career spanning eight decades.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Hans van Manen in Amsterdam in 2024. “Ever since I was 7, all I wanted to do was dance,” he once said.

item.title: James Barnor Has Photographed Ghana Since the 1940s. He Remembers Everything.
item.description: The 96-year-old on postcolonial history, his first camera and the importance of talking to younger artists.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Acheampong

item.title: Christine Choy, Documentarian of Asian American Life, Dies at 76
item.description: Her film “Who Killed Vincent Chin?” earned an Oscar nomination in 1988 and was inducted into the National Film Registry for its cultural significance.
item.dc:creator: Ash Wu

item.title: Ceal Floyer, Incisive Conceptual Artist, Dies at 57
item.description: Her work had a clean, minimal aesthetic at odds with the ambiguities it suggested. It was also unusually accessible.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich

item.title: ‘Here We Go Again’: In Melania Trump’s Movie, This Time She Knows What She’s Doing
item.description: The first lady is behind a movie that she has said will give a better idea of what it was like for her to move into the White House for a second time.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Melania Trump is portrayed as in control and assertive in the trailer for her new movie, “Melania.”

item.title: Timothée Chalamet, Gwyneth Paltrow and Zohran Mamdani Toast ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: With orange beanies, a roast pig and a mayor-elect, the New York premiere of A24’s buzzy Ping-Pong film was its own kind of flick.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Nina Westervelt
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times

item.title: The Most Notable Movies of 2025
item.description: Across the newsroom, journalists picked their most notable movies from 2025.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Goodman, Kyle Buchanan, Joe Coscarelli, Reggie Ugwu, Amanda Webster, Edward Vega and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Gil Gerard, Star of TV Series ‘Buck Rogers,’ Dies at 82
item.description: He was best known for playing the title character in “Buck Rogers in the 25th Century,” which ran on NBC from 1979 to 1981.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Silver Screen Collection/Archive Photos, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Gil Gerard as Buck Rogers, Erin Gray as Wilma Deering and Thom Christopher as Hawk in a 1981 episode of “Buck Rogers in the 25th Century.”

item.title: Billy Crystal, Meg Ryan and Others Remember Rob Reiner as a ‘Master Story Teller’
item.description: A group of prominent figures issued a statement memorializing Mr. Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner. “We were their friends, and we will miss them forever.”
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Rob Reiner, left, with Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan during an anniversary screening of “When Harry Met Sally” in 2019.

item.title: Warner Bros. Urges Shareholders to Reject Paramount Takeover Bid, Saying Ellisons ‘Misled’ Them
item.description: The claim was made as part of Warner Bros. Discovery’s dismissal of Paramount’s hostile takeover offer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warner Bros., which has its headquarters in Burbank, Calif., agreed to sell itself to Netflix in a deal worth $83 billion.

item.title: I Cashed Out My 401(k) to Build a Women-Only Retirement Community
item.description: The Bird’s Nest is experimenting with a different way to age.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Amy Pearl, Sara Curtis, Elisa Gutierrez, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Sonia Herrero, Rowan Niemisto and Marion Lozano

item.title: ‘Who Killed Santa Claus?’: The Night Before Christmas in Occupied France
item.description: This 1941 comic murder mystery is back for a week in a sparkling restoration at Film Forum.
item.dc:creator: J. Hoberman
item.media:description: Raymond Rouleau, left, and Renée Faure in “Who Killed Santa Claus?”

item.title: Late Night Thanks the White House for a ‘Doozy of an Interview’
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel was grateful that Susie Wiles, the president’s “future former chief of staff,” spilled the beans on her boss in a Vanity Fair article.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Tartuffe’ Review: Matthew Broderick and David Cross Face Off
item.description: Matthew Broderick plays Tartuffe and David Cross his naïve prey in this Lucas Hnath adaptation of a 17th-century French comedy classic.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: Matthew Broderick, left, as the title character and David Cross as Orgon in “Tartuffe” at New York Theater Workshop.

item.title: A Second Doctor Is Sentenced in Matthew Perry Ketamine Case
item.description: The doctor, Mark Chavez, who had used fraudulent prescriptions to acquire the drug and conspired to sell it to Mr. Perry at inflated prices, was sentenced to three years of supervised release.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Mark Chavez and another doctor, Salvador Plasencia, worked together to supply the actor Matthew Perry with ketamine at a steep price hike, prosecutors have said.

item.title: What We Know About Nick Reiner, Charged With Killing Rob and Michele Reiner
item.description: The son of Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, who has been charged with two counts of first-degree murder, has long struggled with drug addiction.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Rob Reiner’s star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame on Monday.

item.title: Oscar Shortlists: ‘Sinners,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and ‘Wicked: for Good’ Lead
item.description: The lineups, which Oscar voters will choose from next month, include the new casting category, which was largely a dress rehearsal for best picture.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Hear the Best Albums and Songs of 2025
item.description: 90 tracks! Five hours! Remix the year in pop however you wish.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz
item.media:description: Bad Bunny made both Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz’s lists of the year’s best albums.

item.title: Rob Reiner Gave Us Great Reasons to Go to the Movies
item.description: “This Is Spinal Tap,” “When Harry Met Sally …,” “Misery”: Reiner delivered an incredible number of accessible, original and adult movies that we still cherish.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.category: Spinal Tap II: The End Continues (Movie)
item.media:description: The director Rob Reiner, in 1989, on the set of “When Harry Met Sally …”

item.title: Bristow: A Founding Father of the American Symphony
item.description: George Frederick Bristow, born 200 years ago this month, struggled to find American champions of his music as orchestras favored European tradition.
item.dc:creator: Douglas W. Shadle
item.media:credit: Heritage Art/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: George Frederick Bristow, an American composer who admired the European tradition of classical music and wrote within it.

item.title: Watching ‘Liberation’ With a Women’s Movement Pioneer, My Mom
item.description: In researching her new Broadway play, Bess Wohl interviewed my mother. After a performance, we all discussed the play and its themes.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:description: The cast of “Liberation,” a play that evokes the spirit of sisterhood during the feminist movement of the 1970s.

item.title: ‘Beaches’ Was a Novel. Then a Movie. Next, It’ll Be a Broadway Musical.
item.description: A musical adaptation of the story will open at the Majestic Theater next spring. And yes, the score includes “Wind Beneath My Wings.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Jessica Vosk, left, and Kelli Barrett starred in a production of “Beaches” last year at Theater Calgary in Canada, and will do so again next year on Broadway.

item.title: Tuan Andrew Nguyen Wins High Line Commission
item.description: On the High Line Plinth next spring, the Vietnam-based artist will resurrect an ancient Buddha, destroyed by the Taliban, as a vision of resilience.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage

item.title: Who Is the Ultimate Onscreen Mr. Darcy From ‘Pride and Prejudice’?
item.description: Welcome to our Regency Thunderdome, where we will endeavor to answer this question once and for all.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan, Sarah Lyall and Sadie Stein

item.title: The Best True Crime of 2025: ‘Predators” and More
item.description: Here are four highlights across TV, film and podcasting from the second half of the year.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.category: The Twisted Tale of Amanda Knox (TV Program)

item.title: Late Night Pays Tribute to Rob Reiner
item.description: Seth Meyers also scorned President Trump’s Truth Social post about the celebrated filmmaker’s death.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Nick Reiner’s Struggles With Drugs Left His Parents ‘Desperate’
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who was arrested in connection with the deaths of Rob and Michele Reiner, once estimated he had been in drug treatment 18 times as a teenager.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Nicole Sperling

item.title: Anthony Geary, Luke on ‘General Hospital,’ Dies at 78
item.description: Portraying Luke Spencer, he was one of the best-known soap opera stars in American television. His onscreen romance with Laura Webber, played by Genie Francis, changed the landscape of daytime television.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb

item.title: Rob Reiner Made Clear What He Believed In, Onscreen and Off
item.description: In films like “A Few Good Men,” the director’s ideas of honor and morality were stated as plainly as could be.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Rob Reiner: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The actor-turned-director spent decades at the forefront of the entertainment world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: As Michael Stivic in ‘All in the Family,’ Rob Reiner Brought Political Arguments Home
item.description: Reiner’s “All in the Family” role didn’t just capture the arguments of its time. It gave us a preview of our own.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: Trump’s Post Attacking Rob Reiner After Stabbing Death Draws Immediate Outrage
item.description: The president attributed the killing to “Trump derangement syndrome,” but his disparaging comments drew backlash even from conservative allies who said they were inappropriate.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, at the Kennedy Center in Washington in 2023. The Reiners’ 32-year-old son was “booked for murder,” according to the Los Angeles police chief, Jim McDonnell.

item.title: Rob Reiner’s Movies and TV Shows: ‘When Harry Met Sally,’ ‘The Princess Bride’ and More
item.description: He played one of the most memorable sitcom roles of the ’70s before going on to direct a string of enduring movie classics. Here are some of his career highlights.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: Rob Reiner on the set of “Stand By Me.”

item.title: The Berlin Film Festival Moves Forward Despite Challenges
item.description: The festival, which takes place in winter and late in the award season, has, in recent years, been somewhat overshadowed by its sister events in Cannes and Venice.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:description: The actress Fan Bingbing posing at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival in February. Over the years, the festival has been disadvantaged by its timing in the calendar.

item.title: ‘Titaníque,’ Singing and Spoofing Celine Dion, Sets Sail for Broadway
item.description: This zany musical made it from the basement of a Manhattan grocery to London’s West End, and now hopes to become Broadway’s next hit comedy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Titaníque” team includes, from top to bottom, the director Tye Blue, the writer Constantine Rousouli, the actor Marla Mindelle and the music supervisor Nicholas James Connell.

item.title: Michele Singer Reiner Inspired Rob Reiner to Change the Ending of ‘When Harry Met Sally’
item.description: Mr. Reiner’s falling for his wife of 36 years inspired the director to rework the ending of “When Harry Met Sally …” The couple would collaborate on movies and political causes.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam and Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner in Los Angeles in 2019. The couple had been married over three decades when they were found dead in their home on Sunday.

item.title: What Would Be Lost if We Didn’t Have the HBO Comedy Special
item.description: The potential Warner Bros. Discovery sale might jeopardize a lively outlet for artier stand-up shows like those of Sarah Sherman and Adam Pally.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: Out From Russia’s Shadow: Lithuania’s National Ballet at 100
item.description: The national company has a new leader, Jurgita Dronina, and a desire to raise its profile to a troupe that can rank among Europe’s best.
item.dc:creator: Martha Schabas
item.category: Lithuanian National Opera and Ballet Theater
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jurgita Dronina, left, the new leader of the Lithuanian national company, with the dancer Nora Straukaite.

item.title: 11 New Holiday Albums That Will Make You Gasp, Laugh and Sway
item.description: Fresh entries into the tradition include releases by Luke Bryan, Tyra Banks and Old Crow Medicine Show.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: ‘The Emperor’s New Groove’ at 25: Kronk’s Enduring Appeal
item.description: This millennial favorite wouldn’t be the same without a certain sidekick.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar

item.title: ‘A Christmas Carol’, ‘Dead Outlaw’ and More Theater to Stream
item.description: Other picks include a family production of “The Snow Queen,” the Broadway-bound “Every Brilliant Thing” and the acclaimed comedy “Sorry for Your Loss.”
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sherman

item.title: Olivia Dean, Josh Johnson and Chase Infiniti Are Among Our 2025 Breakout Stars
item.description: Across the arts, these 10 performers took a leap of faith this year and stuck the landing in a big way.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam

item.title: What Can I Watch With My Kids?
item.description: A reader with a 9- and 11-year-old wants to branch out from “Traitors” and “The Amazing Race” when the family is together in front of the TV.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Egner
item.category: All Creatures Great and Small (TV Program)
The Great British Bake Off (TV Program)
Only Murders in the Building (TV Program)
A Series of Unfortunate Events (TV Program)

item.title: As Regional Theaters Struggle, Some Defy the Odds
item.description: Naples, Fla., and Milwaukee are quite different, but have one thing in common: They are home to regional theaters that are thriving.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gulfshore Playhouse in Naples, Fla., is now presenting productions in its new main stage theater with 400 seats, twice the size of its former home.

item.title: Whitney Biennial Names 56 Artists to Unwind These ‘Weird Times’
item.description: The 2026 exhibition focuses on how artists measure American influence and their relationship to a country whose role in the world is changing.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times
item.media:description: Left to right, Marcela Guerrero and Drew Sawyer, curators of the Whitney Biennial 2026, and some of the artists in the exhibition: Agosto Machado (standing); Kamrooz Aram (standing); Samia Halaby (seated), Jonathan González (standing), Precious Okoyomon (seated), Emilie Louise Gossiaux, who is blind.
